segments.text: Today I'm interviewing Kathy Whitmire, mayor of the city of Houston.
Today is November 11, 1983.
First question.

Kathy, do you feel that the people of Houston, with their oil-dealing, ranch-handed image of Houston, require a different strategy for you as a female candidate as opposed to, say, Jane Byrne of Chicago?
Well, I think every city is different.
The electorate in every city is different.
tried to direct my campaigns at the attitudes that I think prevail with Houston's electorate, I'm sure that the ones in Chicago are very different.
Attitudes, which ones prevail in Houston?
Well, I've tried to direct my campaigns at the people in Houston who are generally younger and progressive and open-minded, and that's how I see Houston as a
a city of relative newcomers with a relatively young average age.
What groups would you say have posed more of a problem for you than, say, your male counterparts?
Groups who have posed more of a problem for me than those same groups that have posed for males?
Say, a male mayor.
A male mayor.
I don't know.
I really don't make that much distinction between women and men candidates or elected officials.
I think that it really depends on the individual.
And groups such as the police union, who have been problematic in their dealings with me, have been equally problematic in their dealings with male mayors.
And if I had different positions on the issues, they probably wouldn't
I don't think the gender difference makes that much difference.
Does the fact of you being a female allow you to detract or emphasize the real issues of a campaign?
If so, does this enhance or hurt your posture, and how does it affect voter turnout?
Well, when I first started running for office, the issue of being a female in a city that had never elected a woman to any office

in some respects an advantage for me with the electorate because there were a lot of people who were interested in seeing a qualified female elected to a public office, and I think that did help the turnout, and it certainly helped recruit volunteers to my campaign.
At the same time, it hurt fundraising for the campaign because there was a general view that women would not be successful.
Did it allow you to detract or emphasize the real issues of the campaign, do you think?

I think that there was initially some indication or some tendency for the media to focus more on my being female than on anything else, but ultimately we overcame that and I think ran a very issue-oriented campaign.
In all three of the campaigns that I've run, I think they've been very issue-oriented.
Does the media in any way detract the importance of the issue or ignore certain relevant responses you have towards them?
And is there a difference, say, in the way the Houston Chronicle evaluates you as opposed to the Houston Post?
Well, in any circumstance, the news media is going to put their own interpretation on the issues.
That's just the nature of the situation.
The Chronicle, unfortunately, has a tendency to use their news pages to carry out their editorials.
position and they've done that in both of my campaigns and during my administration and I think that's unfortunate.
The Post does not take editorial positions on elections and as a consequence they have more objective reporting.
And yet still the Chronicle remains the main paper in Houston.
What does that say?
The Chronicle does have the largest distribution and I imagine that says that the people
who are managing and editing the Chronicle and handling its distribution are doing a better job of their business, that is, providing a product which will sell.
A campaign minority, say a black, Hispanic, or a gay, versus a female, which receives more notice in an election and why?
Oh, I think it's probably about equal any time.
A candidate is from some group that is not the traditional white male candidate.
There's a lot of emphasis given to that.
You may remember occasions when Catholics have run for president.
There's been considerable attention given to a member of a religious minority, so to speak.
So I think that there's not any real difference.
That's just one of the ways that people focus on what's unique about this candidate, this candidate's a woman or
is Jewish or is Catholic or is black or whatever.
Obviously different communities value certain qualities.
Would you explain Houston then and how you think they evaluate a female versus, how would you comprise Houston?
Would you start at the beginning of that again?
Evaluate certain qualities.
How would you say Houston's in this respect then?
Go back to what the respect is.
I didn't...
I didn't really understand what you started with.
Different communities value certain qualities above others.
Is it more important to be Mexican or be female?
How would you look at Houston in this respect?
I don't think those are the issues.
I don't think that Houston, as a voting group, thinks it's more important to elect a member of any minority group
versus any other or to elect someone who's not a member of a minority group.
I think that Houston's, that Houstonians on the whole are looking for someone who is fiscal and conservative.
I find that almost across the board that Houstonians want someone who will be responsible in their management of money and that that is a very, very high priority.
And that Houstonians are looking for a candidate who
appears to have the right qualifications and credentials for the job.
Even when it comes to getting a black city council member as opposed to a white?

Well, I think certainly the black community is interested in electing a black city council member, but I don't find at the same time that the white community is opposed to electing a black city council member.
So I thought you were talking about the city as a whole.
Does campaigning force you to become more female or more of a business person, sacrificing your sexuality from 9 to 5?
No, I don't think campaigning forces you to do anything.
Different women have taken different approaches to how to handle their gender in the campaign.
I developed a certain approach that certainly was not a requirement and wouldn't be a requirement of anyone who happens to be a female candidate.
The approach I took was that I was running for office initially in 1977 on my business background.
And that was the basis of my campaign.
And so I worked to present a business-like image to go with that business background.
When you ran, it became an issue of how you dressed.
Do you think, obviously, some men they dress what some people would term outdated.
Do you find it surprising that you're given more attention than as opposed to how males dress?
And what was your reaction to this as opposed to them focusing on the issues?

Well, that is one of the differences of being a female candidate, that the press and the public at large focus more on appearance of females than they do on appearance of males, particularly on dress.
There's just a tendency to focus more on dress of women in any
in any profession or endeavor, not just in politics.
If a female wore a mud sling, how would females view her as opposed to a male that females would see mud sling?
Well, I find that the electorate in general does not appreciate mud sling, whether it's done by a male or a female.
I don't know of any difference in whether
A male candidate or a female candidate engages in mudslinging, I think in both cases it's generally disliked.
You don't see a difference between a male being macho, brash?
No, I think it's generally a bad campaign strategy and in most cases bad pers.
Does a female, such as you, have to assert her views more defined and firmer due to how some females are viewed as being more persuadable?
Yes, I think that's probably true.
I think there's a tendency for people to assume that a woman is not going to be decisive and strong-willed, and I happen to be probably even more strong-willed than I should be.
So I have to make sure that people are aware of that.
How did this affect how you laid down your campaign promises, or did it?
I don't think that it did.
Explain how you feel the impact of the city having its first mayor affected its image.
Having its first female mayor?
Oh, I think that it certainly brought a degree of national attention to the city that we didn't have before.
When you stop to think about the mayors of Houston in the past, if you would have asked someone in Chicago or Atlanta or Detroit who was the mayor of Houston, they probably wouldn't know.
If you asked them today, they probably would know.
So I think it brought some extra attention to the city that we didn't have before.
Explain how your expectations meet up to the reality of being in office, differences and similarities.
Well, the surprises that I found in taking office as mayor...

had mostly to do with the extreme amount of attention that I get from the news media, which I really had not anticipated, and also with the unique situation of finding out what it's like for everyone to know who I am and finding that I have completely lost my privacy and that everywhere I go, everybody knows who I am.
With regard to the management of the office, the only thing that's different from my expectation is that

It really seems to take longer to get things done than I had hoped, because what I have found is that if you want to be successful in the arena of government, you have to check with everyone in advance before you do anything, so that everyone is well-informed, and it just takes longer than it should.
Does the fact that you are female seem to make you more or less representative of establishment to such groups which might feel oppressed by a power of the elite?
Say, how it...
Yeah, I think I see what you mean.

And obviously, since women have not traditionally been known as part of the power establishment, the fact that I'm a woman makes people who feel oppressed by that establishment relate to me more easily.
How strategic was the appointment of the nationally credible black police chief, Captain Brown, and was it successful, and how would you gauge it such?
Well, the appointment of Chief Brown was not a strategy that I planned in advance.
That was a very fortunate incident.
When I found myself in need of a new police chief very early on, I decided to have a national search done.
I, at that time, certainly was not aware that there were any black police chiefs, so I did not set out to look for one by any means.
And when we came down to
the final candidates that seemed to have a lot of potential, it just so happened that one of them was Lee Brown, who happens to be black.
And I think that in the long run that has proved to be a very, very good decision, probably much better than I ever could have anticipated due to his own personal abilities and qualities.
It was not something that I had planned out in advance.
I just set out to find someone who I had confidence in and who could make some reforms in the police department.
And I was fortunate to find someone who I believe will be able to do that.
For Police Chief Brown, you had eight police chiefs in eight years.
The city did.
The city did.
Is that one of the criteria you would say that has helped you measure them by?
Or how would you gauge its success?
Would it be not being in the papers being a plus?
I would gauge his success by being able to set some specific measurable goals and attain those goals.
And by being able to gain the cooperation of people in the department who initially didn't have any intention of cooperating with him.
By being able to go from a time when members of council and members of the employee organizations openly said that they opposed his appointment to the time now.
where all of those people openly say that they agree with his department and that they support his leadership.
Do you think that being a female makes it easier or harder for you to gain credibility with the police department?
Probably harder.
Why?
Because females have only recently been allowed in the police department and

most current members of the department were there at the time when they felt that women were unqualified to do the kind of work they're doing, and so it's easy for them to wonder whether women are qualified to do the kind of work I'm doing.
Do you think that the council deals with a female differently than a male?
On June 15th, 1983, there was
put some term to riot, police department, small.
You mean in the council chambers?
In the council chambers where a few hundred came inside were screaming obscenities.
It seemed that council really didn't support you.
At least the appearance was.
Do you think if you'd have been a male mayor, council would have handled the situation a few differently?
I don't think so at all.
I think every council member had their own view of that situation and most of them are
more tolerant of disorderliness than I am.
There was a city ordinance requiring only a certain number of people to be allowed in there and it was violated.
Why wasn't it able to be enforced?
Because most members of council are more tolerant of disorderliness and believe it should not be enforced.
Even if it includes people screaming obscenities at the mayor of the city of Houston?
Apparently so.
Do you think that the males of the city and on city council have something against looking up to you or working under you as a female?
And how did you feel working under Jim O'Connor as a female male?
I don't think that that made any difference.
Business?
Yeah, it was just a business relationship.
There's the fact that in 1977, it was the International Woman's Year and they had their convention in Houston.
Do you think that that affects the use in Houston is how they look at a female mayor?
I'd say in Dallas, you used to look at a female mayor if they had one?
Probably not.
That was just one event on one weekend, and I think most people in Houston have probably forgotten about it by now.

Do you feel the gay community having a feminist posture, or at least a feminist image in the eyes of society, is more responsive to your policies, and do you feel that you are more sympathetic, if not at least more willing to listen to them, than a male who has to fit the image of going against them to protect himself?
Not at all.
I know many male politicians who get along well with the gay community, and I also know
many men in the gay community who just simply don't like women at all.
What are the special interest groups or, say, supporters that would influence your politics, your policies?
I don't think special interest groups influence my policies.
Cameron Ironwork had to laugh between 2,000 and 2,500 workers.
International Tool Supply, out of 500 workers, had to laugh about 70%.
When you were mayor, you had to lay off less than 50 of the city's workers.
Until the summer of 1982, Houston's employment had been almost sheltered until it caught up with the United States being about 4% less originally.
When this caught up with Houston, did the city apportion you with an undue amount of criticism?
Oh, I don't think so.
Certainly my opponent in this last election
took advantage of the economic recession as something to lay at my doorstep.
And I think that any opponent would have done that.
That's part of running a political campaign.
You blame your opposition with whatever you can.
But I do not feel that I've been unduly blamed for the national economic recession.
Do you think Houston's image has strengthened among mayors and governors of the United States?
with a female as opposed to if a male had accomplished the same results?

Well I think I certainly have a higher profile amongst mayors and governors of the United States because I'm a woman and I also have made it my business to take an active part in national organizations of elected officials and therefore I've become well known by the other mayors around the country.
How could the administration be so out of touch with the voters
when it came to the vote on the Metropolitan Transit Authority bonds, especially when our congressman in DC was even so surprised at the city's action when everyone knew it would be defeated.
Well, I don't know whether everyone knew it would be defeated.
I still think that there was a strategic mistake made in calling that election at a time when only a few people would be voting because I think that the majority of the voters,
The majority of the voters had been in the polls that we passed.
It was the low turnout that caused it to be defeated.
So you're saying that you were in touch with the voters, it's just the ones that you were in touch with didn't show up?
Yeah, I think that's true.
A very small percentage of the people voted, and they all came from a very specific segment of the city.
They were all older voters, older and affluent voters.
And if there had been a large turnout, such as the turnout that voted this week in the mayor's race, I think it probably would have passed.
Will the same vote be taken to the people again?
Not the same, no.
Similar?

What's going to be done is the various alternatives for public transportation systems are going to be reviewed in community meetings around the city to try to get an advanced view of what kind of support there is for the various alternatives.
San Francisco recently passed an ordinance which forbid any smoking in offices, restaurants, and all public facilities.
San Francisco also has a female mayor, Mayor Feinstein.
Do you think you could pass the same sort of legislation in Houston that would, being a female, have any difference in if you tried to pass it as a male?
No, I don't think there's any difference in a male or a female advocating for that particular legislation.
I haven't really reviewed it, so I don't
know whether I would want to pass that particular legislation.
With respect to your relationships with city council, do you feel like you're treated as a gentlewoman or as just another one of the guys on city council?
And what would your preference be?
I'm treated as another one of the guys, and that is my preference.
Do different factions of media, say papers as opposed to radio,
Do different factions measure you differently?
Oh, not intentionally.
I think each type of media has a different approach.
The newspapers, the reporters for the newspapers are always much better informed and get involved in the specifics of the issues much more than the broadcast media.
The television people are generally looking for something that's sensational, and that just relates to what their audiences want.
What are the advantages and disadvantages a female office holder deals with when it comes to getting the job done that you can attribute to being, that you can attribute to sexual honor?
There are really not any.
I'm not a big believer that either men or women are automatically more qualified to do something.
I think that every person is an individual and has to be considered as such.
Well, they might not be more qualified, but do you think that there still are any
things that hold you back in certain areas that, despite qualifications, you're not able to achieve?
No.
Do you think that we as a nation are past the point where we examine females in public to see whether we should move from the testing point and allow it to not hinge on gender anymore?
No, I don't think we're to that point yet.
I think that there's still a small enough number of
women officials that people like me still do get an inordinate amount of public attention because we serve as a role model or an example of what women are like in public office.
Do you think we'll ever have a female president?
Certainly.
How soon?
I don't know.
No guesses?
No.
All things happen eventually.
You went to school in the Houston Independent School District, HISD.
You went to San Jacinto High School.
What is your feeling then and what is your feeling now on the quality of the education?
Well, I think I got a good education in HISD.
I knew at the time that there were some differences in the level of educational opportunity that was provided at different schools.
When I graduated from high school, generally, Bel Air High School was thought to be the most advanced, and their students had the opportunity to take the most advanced courses.
San Jacinto was not really in the same league with Bel Air, but at the same time, I felt I had the opportunity to get a good education there.
I'm sure there are still those differences.
I saw that in the late 60s and early 70s, there was a lot of decline in the quality of education in HISD and specifically in the quality of discipline.
And I think that in the last 10 years, we have seen some improvements.
We've seen some improvements in the type of opportunities that are provided through the magnet program and through the VANDVARD program.
And we're beginning to see some improvements in the discipline, which I think is very important.
Administrators have typically been males while the teachers of America's grade schools have typically been females.
How has HSD's weak image affected your dealings with the administration of this system?
Well, I really don't have a lot of dealings with the administration of the school system since they are an independent school district and not subject to any policy determinations from the city.
Does being a woman help bolster public opinion in your favor when you at least say your feelings towards education?
I really don't take public positions on education very often since it's not within the realm of responsibilities that the city has.
Governor White has a strong stance on education.
Have you had any dealings with Governor White on this issue?
I have had a lot of dealings with Governor White, mostly on other issues.
I have talked with him about his views on education and certainly respect his views as a strong supporter of education.
What are your views?

I think that the public school system is one of the most important aspects of what a city offers to its citizens and that it is extremely important to be able to provide a quality education for the public school system.
Have we achieved that quality?

I think there is still room for improvement, and I think that while Governor White is working actively to improve pay scales for teachers, that there are two things that are going to have to be done to ultimately attract the kind of quality people that we need and retain them in education.

One of those is that we're going to have to have year-round school, because you can't expect someone to make a living on a nine-month salary, and you can't expect them to earn a 12-month salary if they only work nine months.
So that's one thing that's going to have to change.
And the other thing that's going to have to change is that teachers are going to have to be compensated according to merit.
They can't just be compensated across the board and expect to retain big performers.
Do you believe in paying teachers according to ability or according to years?
According to ability.
Do you think that that will be possible in HISD?
I certainly hope so.
And once again, that's not one of the things that comes under the jurisdiction of the city.
So what I'm offering is just my personal opinion.
Do you feel that women are more comprehensible or are more sympathetic towards education since they have the image of being the teachers of our nation?
Well, that's certainly conventional wisdom, that women are more interested in education.
On the other hand, I find that many business people are extremely aware of the importance of quality
education, and many businessmen are aware of that.
Houston has traditionally, at least in the eyes of the public, had a poor school system by national standards.
It was nationally ranked 18th out of the 22 largest metropolitan cities, and it's ranked in the top five, with Dallas being second in the segregation of the school district.
What sort of long-term goals do you think should be set for HISD
And how do you think the strength and quality of the Spring Branch Independent School District fits into a picture like this?
Well, of course, both the Spring Branch School District and the Houston Independent School District, as well as a couple of others, are included within the City of Houston.
And my hope is that all of those school districts can set some very high standards for the type of educational opportunity that is provided

for young people growing up in Houston because I think that public education is just extremely important and that a higher emphasis needs to be placed on educational achievement than we have seen perhaps in the past.
What do you think has allowed Spring Branch Independent School District to obviously surpass a quality education in HISD?
I'm not really aware that it has surpassed HISD.
Perhaps it has, I'm just not informed.
Do you think it's all in the games of economics?
Well, I really couldn't comment on it since I don't necessarily know that the premise is true.
Explain your relationship with Billy Reagan and how you evaluate him in his job.
Well, my relationship with Billy Reagan is a good one.
We have a good working relationship on the issues that we have in common.
The city has some contractual relationships with the school district.
for the collection of taxes and the appraisal of tax property, and we do work together from the standpoint of planning our tax situation.
We also have a few other programs that we've worked on jointly with regard to after-school programs in cooperation with our Parks Department and the Houston Independent School District.
I think that during the years that Billy Reagan has been with the Houston Independent School District, he has
accomplished some significant improvements in the programming and in the quality of education.
And I'm generally a supporter of his.
Do you think he's coming towards the end of his ability to justify his existence in the school system?
Or do you think that he has a lot more to offer?
I think he has more to offer.
On June 15, 1983, you had an incident with the police department.
The Houston Police Department is the second highest paid in the nation behind Los Angeles.
But in real terms, LA has a higher cost of living.
And so Houston's the highest paid police department.
They seem to put out an image of being rednecks and providing low quality service.
And the city's very aware of this image.
Do you think that this image, do you think that the frustration that they feel, do you think that that was shown in
the council meeting, would you like to explain why you think the circumstances came to be?
I don't think the incident in the council meeting has anything to do with their image.
I think it had entirely to do with the union leaders who were unable to get acquiescence from this administration for their financial demands, both in terms of pay and benefits.
And that's really what it was about.
Now, on the subject of
HPD's image.
They have had a bad national image in the past, but I think since Chief Brown has been here, we have seen some improvement in that image.
We've seen some improvement in the professional standards in the department, and I'm looking forward to more improvements in the future.
Being in real terms the highest paid department in the nation, were their demands justified?
No.
Why not?
Because of what you just explained, that they already are the highest paid in the nation, and
Obviously, I think we all understand that the job of a union leader under any circumstance is to go out and fight for higher pay and higher benefits, no matter how high they already are.
And those union leaders were trying to do their job in their regard.
